customer_addr:
5380 West Whitley Road
South Whitley, IN 46787

citations.narrative:
The facility is conducting regulated brokering activity without a valid brokers license from USDA APHIS Animal Care
under the Animal Welfare Act (AWA). The facility has brokered two puppies in the past three weeks and is in the process
of trying to sell another puppy that she obtained from another breeder. Conducting brokering activity without a valid USDA
brokers license doesn't ensure the licensee is approved for that specific brokering activity. Continuing to conduct
brokering activity without a valid brokers license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act. The customer must either stop all
brokering activity or must obtain a USDA brokering license.
NO BROKERING ACTIVITIES MAY BE CONDUCTED UNTIL A LICENSE IS OBTAINED.
Correct starting on 8/5/25.

The licensee sold two puppies approximately three weeks ago, but does not have any records documenting those sales.
Not having disposition records (APHIS Form 7006) for those dogs doesn't allow APHIS officials to be able to track the
movement of dogs through the kennel. All disposition records (APHIS Form 7006) must be documented for every dog.
Correct starting on 8/5/25.

The licensee does not currently have a contingency plan in place. Not having a contingency plan doesn't ensure the
facility will be prepared in the event of an emergency or disaster. The licensee must complete the contingency plan in
accordance with the requirements outlined in the Animal Welfare Act. Correct by 9/5/25.

Prior to the inspection even starting, I observed three german shepherd puppies running around the yard. At the start of
the inspection, it was determined the puppies escaped their enclosure. Their outdoor part of their enclosure was at the
end of the building. The fence post for their enclosure was not stable and was pushed/slid off the cement surface and the
side of the enclosure was able to swing open like a gate allowing the pups to escape. Housing facilities that are not
structurally sound and allow for the dogs to escape does not ensure the safety and welfare of the dogs. The dogs could
get preyed on by another animal, hit by a car, or injured/killed in a number of ways. The enclosure must be fixed so it
contains the dogs securely. Correct starting on 8/5/25.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
End of report.
n

narrative:
2.1(b)(1) 
   
Requirements and application 
The facility is conducting regulated brokering activity without a valid brokers license from USDA APHIS Animal Care 
under the Animal Welfare Act (AWA). The facility has brokered two puppies in the past three weeks and is in the process 
of trying to sell another puppy that she obtained from another breeder. Conducting brokering activity without a valid USDA 
brokers license doesn't ensure the licensee is approved for that specific brokering activity. Continuing to conduct 
brokering activity without a valid brokers license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act. The customer must either stop all 
brokering activity or must obtain a USDA brokering license. 
 
NO BROKERING ACTIVITIES MAY BE CONDUCTED UNTIL A LICENSE IS OBTAINED. 
 
Correct starting on 8/5/25. 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee sold two puppies approximately three weeks ago, but does not have any records documenting those sales. 
Not having disposition records (APHIS Form 7006) for those dogs doesn't allow APHIS officials to be able to track the 
movement of dogs through the kennel. All disposition records (APHIS Form 7006) must be documented for every dog. 
Correct starting on 8/5/25. 
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The licensee does not currently have a contingency plan in place. Not having a contingency plan doesn't ensure the 
facility will be prepared in the event of an emergency or disaster. The licensee must complete the contingency plan in 
accordance with the requirements outlined in the Animal Welfare Act. Correct by 9/5/25. 
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Prior to the inspection even starting, I observed three german shepherd puppies running around the yard. At the start of 
the inspection, it was determined the puppies escaped their enclosure. Their outdoor part of their enclosure was at the

end of the building. The fence post for their enclosure was not stable and was pushed/slid off the cement surface and the 
side of the enclosure was able to swing open like a gate allowing the pups to escape. Housing facilities that are not 
structurally sound and allow for the dogs to escape does not ensure the safety and welfare of the dogs. The dogs could 
get preyed on by another animal, hit by a car, or injured/killed in a number of ways. The enclosure must be fixed so it 
contains the dogs securely. Correct starting on 8/5/25. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
End of report. 
 
 n
